our worst day in government,'' a senior aide from David Cameron 's Downing Street office told The Guardian, after Andy Coulson quit as chief of communications on Friday. The left-wing newspaper added that Andy Coulson 's departure leaves the prime minister with a crucial vacancy as the coalition government weathers dissent about cuts in public spending introduced to reduce a huge budget deficit. Andy Coulson had been under pressure for months about what he knew about a phone-hacking scandal at the Rupert MurJean-Claude Duvalierh-owned News of the World weekly in 2005-6,

to phone messages of royal household staff. He has always denied any knowledge of wrongdoing at the newspaper. Cameron has defended his own judgement in hiring Andy Coulson , saying he felt the former editor had been punished twice for the same offence.
